deed.name: The Abyss of Mordath: The Master of the Seven -- Tier 2
deed.description: King Váskmun Greytooth has come to the Mordath seeking the lost Dwarf-ring, Manthríf, and will stop at nothing to reclaim it. However, the fates of the Seven are shrouded in great secrecy and terrible truths shall soon be revealed.

objective.text: King Váskmun Greytooth has come to the Mordath seeking the lost Dwarf-ring, Manthríf, and will stop at nothing to reclaim it. However, the fates of the Seven are shrouded in great secrecy and terrible truths shall soon be revealed.

enterDetection.loreInfo: You have defeated Fingar the Greedy, a great Worm of Angband in the depths of the Mordath. As King Váskmun Greytooth's greed led only to his doom, the true fate of Manthríf remains unknown.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Prevent King Váskmun Greytooth from recovering Manthríf

deed.name: Sovereign of Seregost
deed.description: Deep within Seregost, Lhaereth the Stained keeps her plague cauldrons. They contain a new, more virulent Great Plague, which she intends to release upon the realms of the Free Peoples. As you and the Rangers Faeron and Rhadrog are the few innoculated to the plague, you must enter the Court of Seregost as a small strike team and attempt to disrupt Lhaereth's plans.

deed.name: The Abyss of Mordath -- Explorer of the Black Pits
deed.description: The Abyss of Mordath is home to both the condemned of Mordor and the Dark Lord's most carefully-guarded secrets.

objective.text: You must explore the deepest depths of the Mordath to uncover all that was hidden away by Sauron.

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: You have discovered the Lithannon, the Ashen Gate, of the Mordath. Once the main entrance into the Mordath, it has been sealed in the wake of Sauron's defeat.

Although it has been shattered, Durshnúl, The Black Bridge, once spanned the sunken Abyss of Mordath and was a great highway for both the damned of the Black Pits and the imprisoned creatures of the Dark Lord.

The Mordath, the Black Pits of Mordor, is a place devoid of hope. It is the foundation of Barad-dûr, an ever-deepening mine, and a pit of punishment for those that have failed the Dark Lord. Those who are cast into the Black Pits will never again behold the light of Middle-earth.

Thol Shíkug is a fortress of terror and death built into the very foundations of Barad-dûr. For those condemned to the Black Pits, it is known as the Screaming Deep -- for many an Orc, Man, and beast have met their ends at the hands of the Dark Lord and his most powerful servants within. What lies within this grim structure, none have ever returned to tell.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Thol Shíkug, the Screaming Deep

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: Murpraush, the Hall of Spoiling, is where Sauron conducted the most vile of his sorceries. It was there he sought to equal the horrors of the first Dark Lord, Morgoth, and bring forth new and terrible creatures of his own imagining.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Murpraush, the Hall of Spoiling

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: Glúrghash, The Pit of Flame, was once the prison of Thostír the Rank, a great fire-drake of the East. After devouring one of the Seven Rings, he was captured by agents of Mordor and imprisoned beneath Barad-dûr. However, when the Mordath was split asunder, he flew from its shadowed depths and escaped the Land of Shadow.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Glúrghash, The Pit of Flame

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: Glúrakul, The Pit of Frost, was once home to Hrímil Frost-heart, a cold-drake of the Grey Mountains. After Hrímil came to the dwarf-halls in the East and devoured one of the Seven Rings, he was captured and imprisoned beneath the Dark Tower. However, when Barad-dûr fell and the Mordath was shattered, he flew from his prison and escaped from Mordor.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Glúrakul, The Pit of Frost

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: Glurnákh, The Pit of Greed, has long been the home to Fingar the Greedy, an ancient Worm of Angband. After devouring two of the Seven Rings, Fingar was captured and imprisoned beneath the Dark Tower to suffer evermore.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Glurnákh, The Pit of Greed

deed.name: The Lay of Rust and Rime
deed.description: Late in the Third Age, an old conflict stirred between the Weeping Warrior and the Herald of Winter.

objective.text: Experience the events of the Lay of Rust and Rime.

questComplete.loreInfo: You learned of a series of intertwining rumours that confounded the Men of Lake-town and Dale. Who or what is the Herald of Winter? Has Vethúg Wintermind grown weary of his hoards in the Ered Mithrin, or does another of the Gúrzyul come to spread fear and destruction in the North?

You learned that the agents of the Weeping Warrior have been gathering cold-drakelings in Lake-town under the cover of night. After eavesdropping on a conversation between a smuggler and one of Karazgar's servants, you learned that not only does Karazgar hope to use the drakelings to bolster his strength, but also to send a message to the Herald of Winter and the North itself. You also discovered that Karazgar travelled into Eryn Lasgalen, but his purposes remain unclear.

At King Thorin's request, you sought an audience with King Thranduil. You offered him a token of peace from the dwarves of Erebor, and delivered a warning that Karazgar now stalked the realm of the Elves. King Thranduil prepared his scouts and you aided in directing them to seek Karazgar among the forest of Eryn Lasgalen. What will their searches reveal?

Despite learning that Karazgar may have returned to Caras Tilion, King Thranduil was forced to turn his attention to another matter. The Old Mother, Iphantemel, was revealed in Torech Emel, and the time had come at last to claim vengeance upon her for the destruction of Caras Tilion and the blighting of Mirkwood. Far from the hale foe Thranduil once faced, Iphantemel was old and bloated in her excess and she seemed to welcome her death. The spiders were at last purged from Eryn Lasgalen, but only because Ungwetári called her children to the Ephel Dúath for some terrible purpose. King Thranduil became suspicious of Karazgar's intentions in travelling to Caras Tilion and vowed to seek him with a small company of Elves.

After King Thranduil travelled to Caras Tilion, he was beset by the forces of Karazgar. King Thranduil battled Karazgar in single combat, but before the tide of battle turned, he found himself awoken outside Felegoth as if from a trance. Fearing that Karazgar sought the power of the mysterious Green Lady, King Thranduil sent you to Caras Tilion to challenge Karazgar. You discovered the aftermath of a battle between Elves and the Men of Mordor, but Karazgar left only rust in his wake. The Green Lady was revealed, but her intentions remain unclear. What powers does she possess? Is she of the same kind as the Huntsman of Dunland?

After the darkness of Mirkwood at last began to recede, Tárasánë, the Green Lady, revealed herself in Caras Tilion. In a powerful vision, Tárasánë revealed that Vethúg Wintermind will come to Erebor, but as merely a harbinger of the true Herald of Winter. Although Tárasánë would not speak of the Herald of Winter's name, she told you that the Herald of Winter once served the will of Morgoth and has dwelt in Middle-earth since the Elders Days. You returned to King Thranduil with these troubling tidings, and he sent word to the Queen Regent and King Under the Mountain.

At long last, Karazgar revealed his designs in Esgaroth-of-old. The broken remains of the cold-drakelings his agents captured from the furthest reaches of the Ered Mithrin had been laid bare among the bones of Smaug the Golden. It was a deception to enrage the greater drakes in the service of the Herald of Winter and turn their ire against the Elves, Men, and dwarves of the North. A dying cold-drake revealed that one of his kin escaped Karazgar's wrath in Esgaroth-of-old and made for the Ered Mithrin to deliver a warning to the Herald of Winter. Despite the efforts of the leaders of the North, it seems the vile plot of the Weeping Warrior has succeeded.

After you revealed to King Thorin that Vethúg Wintermind seeks to set siege to Erebor, he prepared to rally the forces of the North to repel the legendary cold-drake. Fearful that Vethúg does indeed serve one greater, he has resolved to slay the cold-drake and avenge his ancestors who dwelt in the Ered Mithrin. After an ill-advised attempt at humour, King Thorin requested that you deliver word to the leaders in the North. Although some offered help only begrudgingly, it seems the North remains united against the servants of the Enemy.

While the rest of the North braced for the coming of Vethúg Wintermind, Dís summoned King Thorin III to Ravenhill. To their surprise, the raven-chief, Arcah, had returned from far-off lands and wished to speak with the new King Under the Mountain. After agreeing to honour the old ways between their peoples, Arcah sent her ravens far and wide to spy on both Karazgar and Vethúg Wintermind.

Fearing that you were misled by the visions of the Green Lady, King Thorin III advised you to seek the counsel of King Thranduil. In turn, King Thranduil suggested you seek the counsel of Lady Galadriel and the power of the Mirror. After travelling to Caras Galadhon, Lady Galadriel did not believe that Karazgar could have come so far south to enter the ruins of Dol Guldur beneath the notice of the Galadhrim. Lady Galadriel consulted the Mirror, but again saw no sign of Karazgar in Dol Dhannen, the name now given to Dol Guldur. Still, she felt that something remained beyond her sight and thought long on what was to be done.

After much deliberation, Lady Galadriel travelled to Dol Dhannen with Lord Celeborn, King Thranduil, Sigileth, and you. Your exploration of the ruins of Dol Dhannen nearly proved fruitless until you discovered a small passage leading down into the shadowed tunnels of Gostador. As Lady Galadriel expected, you did not find Karazgar in its depths. However, a great evil still lingered in Gostador and you witnessed shadowy impressions of Karazgar's final dealings with Sauron in Dol Guldur. You learned that Karazgar was promised the entirety of the North once the peoples there were driven out, and that the Weeping Warrior could subjugate or destroy any of the dragons that remained in that realm. You also learned that Hrímil Frost-heart defied Sauron and devoured one of the Dwarf-rings in spite. Following these revelations, you returned to Erebor and informed King Thorin III that Karazgar may still lurk nearby.

The raven-chief, Arcah, called back her ravens from their spying, but not all made the return journey safely. You rescued a wounded raven from swift cold-drakelings that pursued it onto the slopes of Erebor, and soon after, it was able to fly to Ravenhill. However, the tidings it brought did not bode well for the peoples of the North. Vethúg Wintermind had begun his flight from the Grey Mountains, and he would soon lay his vengeance of upon the North.

After learning that Vethúg Wintermind flies for Erebor, the peoples of the North began to ready their defences in earnest. You aided the peoples of Dale, Lake-town, and Felegoth in preparing for battle and defending their homes.

Like the coming of a great storm, Vethúg Wintermind descended upon Erebor in rage and vengeance. Many peoples of the North battled and fell, but in the end, Vethúg sustained a grave wound and flew for the Grey Mountains in defeat.

In the aftermath of the battle at Erebor, it was revealed by the ravens that Karazgar pursued the wounded Vethúg Wintermind into the Grey Mountains. Much to the dismay of his kinfolk, King Thorin III decreed that no expeditions shall be made into the Grey Mountains for he, Erna, and Thranduil think it wise to remain uninvolved in the conflict between Karazgar and Vethúg Wintermind now that they have left the North.

Despite his edict, King Thorin III has heard troubling rumours regarding the forming of an expedition to reclaim Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep, from the dragons and Orcs of the Grey Mountains. Every dwarf you spoke to denied such an expedition, but King Thorin III remained unconvinced. After talking to the adventurous Dori and learning that he has no intent to defy the King Under the Mountain, he asked you to talk to Nori about a group of dwarves who came to the coffers in the night. To the surprise of all in Erebor, Nori departed and led an expedition into the Grey Mountains. King Thorin III was furious, but he would not violate his own edict. The fate of the expedition to Thikil-gundu is Nori's burden to bear.

deed.name: The Path of the Company
deed.description: Follow the path of Thorin and Company through Eryn Lasgalen and the Dale-lands.

objective.text: Follow the path of Thorin and Company through Eryn Lasgalen and the Dale-lands.

enterDetection.loreInfo: \qO good-bye and go away!\q grunted the dwarves, who were secretly filled with dismay at losing him.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company entered Mirkwood

enterDetection.loreInfo: Well, it was not true that they could see nothing: they could see eyes!
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company grew to hate the forest

enterDetection.loreInfo: Bombur slept for days, and dreamt of great Elvish feasts. His memory of their adventures thus far were gone.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bombur fell into the Enchanted River

enterDetection.loreInfo: He saw all around him a sea of dark green, and hundreds of black butterflies.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bilbo climbed above the trees

enterDetection.loreInfo: They saw a gathering of Elves feasting. They ran towards them to beg for food, but as soon as they approached, the Elves vanished!
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company was lured off the path

enterDetection.loreInfo: He beat the creature off with his hands, until he remembered his sword!
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company is ambushed by Spiders

enterDetection.loreInfo: Somehow the killing of the giant spider, all alone by himself in the dark without the help of anyone else, made a great difference to Mr. Baggins. He felt a different person.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bilbo frees the Company from webs

enterDetection.loreInfo: Thorin responded: \qI don't know, but I expect starving in the forest!\q
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Thorin was brought before the Elvenking

enterDetection.loreInfo: Thranduil ordered the dwarves to be put into seperate cells and ordered them not to be released until one of them told him what he wanted to know.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company was jailed by the Elvenking

enterDetection.loreInfo: When Bilbo explained his plan, the dwarves started grumbling loudly in spite of their danger.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company stuffed themselves into barrels

enterDetection.loreInfo: The Elves were making a raft of the barrels, with the dwarves still inside, and would soon be steering it downstream to Lake-town.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the barrels came ashore near Loeglond

enterDetection.loreInfo: \qIf you want to go on with this silly adventure, you had better slap your arms and rub your legs and try and help me get the others out while there is a chance!\q
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bilbo freed the Company from their barrels

enterDetection.loreInfo: Many of the Lake-men took up song, and it rolled loud and high over the Lake.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Thorin declared himself before the Master of Lake-town

enterDetection.loreInfo: None of the men from Lake-town would stay with them even for a night so near the shadow of the Mountain.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company landed at the top of the Long Lake

enterDetection.loreInfo: From Ravenhill, they could see the grey ruins of ancient houses, towers, and walls.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where they scouted the slopes of the Mountain

enterDetection.loreInfo: A gleam of light came straight though the opening, and then there was a loud crack. A hole appeared suddenly about three feet off the ground. Thorin put the key from his grandfather's map into the hole. It fitted and turned! A door five feet high and three broad was outlined, and slowly swung inwards.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the company found the secret way into Erebor

enterDetection.loreInfo: You have discovered the entrance to Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep. When the Steel Keep fell to the Dragons of the Withered Heath, the Dwarves of Durin's Folk fled the ancient halls of Thikil-gundu and left it to its fate as a frozen ruin.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Discover the entrance to Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep

deed.name: Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep -- Tier 1
deed.description: In the wake of Vethúg Wintermind's defeat at Erebor, Nori set forth with a small company to reclaim the lost hoards of Thikil-gundu. However, great wealth is not all that remains hidden in its frozen halls, and the Dwarves of the North shall soon have to contend with the true master of Thikil-gundu.

enterDetection.loreInfo: You have completed 'Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep (Tier 1)'.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Complete 'Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep (Tier 1)'

deed.name: Delver of Thikil-gundu
deed.description: Long before the great cold-drake Vethúg Wintermind froze the halls of Thikil-gundu, the Longbeards delved the Steel Keep in the depths of the Grey Mountains.

objective.text: The halls of Thikil-gundu delve deep into the Wrathhorn.

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: You have discovered Durûz-mazal, the Chamber of Faces. Erected to honour the Dwarrowmoot of old between the Seven Kings of the Dwarves, the many faces of this chamber watch over Thikil-gundu.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Durûz-mazal, the Chamber of Faces

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: You have discovered Bekâr-mazal, the Arming-chamber. Despite housing many weapons and tools of war, the great armoury of Thikil-gundu did not avail the Dwarves of the Steel Keep in the battle against Vethúg Wintermind.

You have discovered the Smithies of Kall-khebâb. Once a great craft-hall of Thikil-gundu, the old smithies of the Steel Keep have been seized by the Orcs of Gundabad in service to the brood of Vethúg Wintermind and his forebear, Hrímil Frost-heart.

You have discovered Balb-gundu, the Frostdelf. One of the only remaining delvings of Thikil-gundu, the Frostdelf once comprised much of Thikil-gundu until a great portion of it collapsed into the Depths of Akhatâr. It now serves as the lair of Athramóth, the mate of Vethúg Wintermind and mother of countless dragon-kind in the Grey Mountains.
You have discovered Zashar-tûmun, the Ruin-dwellings. Once a great dwelling-hall of the Dwarves of Thikil-gundu, Zashar-tûmun has fallen to ruin.

You have discovered the Feast-house of Amrâg-zahar. In the course of many long years, both the Longbeards and Zhélruka enjoyed great feasts and merriment in Amrâg-zahar before the fall of the Steel Keep. When Durin's Folk sought to return to Thikil-gundu, it was there Vethúg Wintermind waited in ambush and descended to slay Dáin, Frór, and countless other Longbeards.

You have discovered the Lore-trove of Afhân-binnîn. A great hall of lore lost to the Longbeards and Zhélruka. Many of its works have been brought to ruin, either by time or by the breath of cold-drakes, but a few pieces of note may still remain in the shadows of Afhân-binnîn.
You have discovered the Depths of Akhatâr. These shadowed pits have not been mapped by any living dwarf, but who knows what could dwell in the depths of the Grey Mountains?
You have discovered Razûkh-zahari, the Room of Rain. A great underground river travels beneath the Grey Mountains, and passes through a carefully-delved crack above the Room of Rain.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Discover Razûkh-zahari, the Room of Rain

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: You have discovered Thikil-nesad, the Steel Seat. Once the seat of countless Kings of the Longbeards and Zhélruka, Thikil-nesad was abandoned when the Steel Keep fell to Vethúg Wintermind.

You have discovered the Hoarding-vault of Immêsh-khalt. Frozen beneath a layer of impenetrable ice, the Hoarding-vault of Immêsh-khalt is lined with the combined wealth of Durin's Folk and the Zhélruka.

deed.name: Where Death Lies In Wait
deed.description: A lingering evil has long remained hidden in the Steel Keep, and it now threatens to overwhelm the dwarves of the North.

objective.text: A lingering evil has long remained hidden in the Steel Keep, and it now threatens to overwhelm the dwarves of the North.

questComplete.loreInfo: The fate of Thikil-gundu remains uncertain, but your efforts have banished the evils that sought shelter in the halls of the Steel Keep.

deed.name: Lost Lore of the Dwarf-holds: Thikil-gundu
deed.description: Built by the dwarves and stolen by dragons, Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep, has borne witness to a tragic and terrible history.

questComplete.loreInfo: You have learned the history of Thikil-gundu from the perspective of Karazgar, the Weeping Warrior.
questComplete.progressOverride: Discover and compile the lost lore of Thikil-gundu

deed.name: Reclaimer of Thikil-gundu
deed.description: Before the coming of Hrímil Frost-heart and her spawn, Vethúg Wintermind, the Steel Keep was home to both the Longbeards and Zhélruka over the course of many long years. In the wake of Vethúg's defeat at Erebor, Nori set forth with a small company to reclaim the lost hoards of Thikil-gundu. However, great wealth is not all that remains hidden in its frozen halls, and the Dwarves of the North shall soon have to contend with the true master of Thikil-gundu if what was lost might still be reclaimed.

objective.text: Before the coming of Hrímil Frost-heart and her spawn, Vethúg Wintermind, the Steel Keep was home to both the Longbeards and Zhélruka over the course of many long years. In the wake of Vethúg's defeat at Erebor, Nori set forth with a small company to reclaim the lost hoards of Thikil-gundu. However, great wealth is not all that remains hidden in its frozen halls, and the Dwarves of the North shall soon have to contend with the true master of Thikil-gundu if what was lost might still be reclaimed.

deed.name: Treats or Trickery: Just a Taste
deed.description: You donned the costume and went from door to neighbourhood door. But have you tasted each kind of treat?

objective.text: You should try one of each type of treat that can be gathered from Treats or Trickery doormats: apple goblins, honey-bears, liquorice twists, Midgewater marshmallows, jam tarts, mint turtles, mad Baggins' gold, and Ent-bark.

itemUsed.loreInfo: An apple, baked until soft and sweet, then imaginitively decorated.
Based on third-party accounts of the Beornings' famed honey-cakes, these bear but the slightest resemblance.
Many assume 'twist' describes what one's mouth does upon tasting these.
Hobbit children hold that there is a real midge hidden in every one.
A secret medley of Shire berries. Sticky fingers, guaranteed.
Not too minty, and the nuts inside are superb.
What began as a bit of a joke became, over time, one of the Harvest Festival's most prized treats.
Of course it isn't made of actual Ents! Don't believe everything Prisca Boffin's children tell you.

deed.name: Treats or Trickery: Clearing the Table
deed.description: You have sampled wide and eaten deep of the Harvest Festival treats, but can you truly say you know each of them as well as the back of your own teeth?

objective.text: Complete Treats or Trickery: Second Helpings

questComplete.loreInfo: You may be somewhat queasy from all the treats you have eaten, but you have not yet made yourself properly ill.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete Treats or Trickery: Second Helpings

objective.text: You should consume a large number of every type of treat that can be gathered from Treats or Trickery doormats: apple goblins, honey-bears, liquorice twists, Midgewater marshmallows, jam tarts, mint turtles, mad Baggins' gold, and Ent-bark.

itemUsed.loreInfo: You could almost swear the little thing sneered at you.
Too sweet... too sweet to possibly bear.
Your mouth has twisted so far around it has nearly become a grin.
The more you cram into your mouth at once, the less you notice... whatever those specks might be.
Some are tarred and feathered. You are to be jammed and crumb-flecked.
After about the eleventh, you begin to suspect their little suspicious eyes watch you as you raise them to your mouth.
It suddenly strikes you that you know where the actual gold must be. It is beneath the party tree, of course. Or no, in Gamgee's garden. Or here, here in your pockets all along.
Your mouth becomes so dry, it might just be tree-bark for all that you can say.

deed.name: Treats or Trickery: Second Helpings
deed.description: You have tasted every type of treat that could be gathered from a doormat during Harvest Festival once, to be sure, but have you made yourself truly sick on them?

objective.text: Complete Treats or Trickery: Just a Taste

questComplete.loreInfo: Tasting merely eight Harvest Festival treats is simply not enough.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete Treats or Trickery: Just a Taste

objective.text: You should consume a large number of the Treats or Trickery treats, to say that you truly know them well.

deed.name: A Chronicle of the Company
deed.description: Follow the path of Thorin and Company through the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Follow the path of Thorin and Company through the Vales of Anduin.

enterDetection.loreInfo: He was through, with coat torn, running down the steps, while confused goblins were still picking up his buttons at the gate.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bilbo lost his buttons

enterDetection.loreInfo: How they jumped! Gandalf was astonished, as they all shouted with surprise and delight.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bilbo reunites with the Company

enterDetection.loreInfo: You would have laughed, if you had seen the dwarves, up in the trees with their beards hanging down, like old gentlemen.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company encountered Wargs

enterDetection.loreInfo: Gandalf, had once kindly assisted the eagles and healed their lord from an arrow-wound.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Eagles took the Company to safety

enterDetection.loreInfo: 'Farewell! Wherever you fare, until your eyrie receive you at your journey's end!'
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Eagles set down the Company

enterDetection.loreInfo: 'This is not my adventure. I may look in on you again before it is over, for I have some rather pressing business to attend to.'
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company gathered at the Carrock

enterDetection.loreInfo: They were bigger than your thumb, much bigger, and the bands of yellow on their black bodies shone a radiant gold.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company walked through Beorn's bee-pastures

enterDetection.loreInfo: 'Here they are! They don't look dangerous.' Beorn laughed a great, low laugh, and put down his axe.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company came upon Beorn's house

enterDetection.loreInfo: 'A very good tale!' said Beorn. 'The best I have heard for a long while. Let's have something to eat!'
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Beorn meets the Company

enterDetection.loreInfo: The dwarves' beards quivered as they listened, for they knew that soon they must venture into the Mirkwood.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company had supper with Beorn

enterDetection.loreInfo: 'I hope you like the look of it. Now you must send back Beorn's ponies that you have borrowed.'
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where the Company enters the Mirkwood

enterDetection.loreInfo: There, far away was the Lonely Mountain on the edge of the horizon. Snow remaining on its highest peak, unmelted and gleaming.
enterDetection.progressOverride: Where Bilbo returns home

monsterDied.loreInfo: 'They called it Orchost, but it is better known by another name: Goblin-town. Indeed, once it was a dwarf-delving, the High Hold of Zudrâligal. But the dwarves were driven out and the goblins made it their own. They stripped out most remnants of the dwarves, leaving only the barest traces of its former ancestry.' - Gandalf the Wizard
monsterDied.progressOverride: Defeat many goblins in the Vales of Anduin

deed.name: Quests of the Gladdenmere
deed.description: Complete many quests in the Gladdenmere.

objective.text: Complete many quests in the Gladdenmere.

questComplete.loreInfo: Once a beautiful lake, the Gladdenmere was wracked by upheavals during the War of the Last Alliance, and the land all about became a vast marshland, a perilous waste of dark pools and tangled grasses. The Gladdenmere has once again become accessible, but the path that allows curious travellers to reach it also allows passage for dangerous foes who might threaten the Wilderfolk of the Vales....

deed.name: Vales Warg-slayer
deed.description: Defeat many wargs in the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Defeat many wargs in the Vales of Anduin.

monsterDied.loreInfo: 'That was the largest warg I have ever seen, and the smartest. I have heard that they grow even larger in Mordor, but that does not concern me. Now, if those were to possess the wits of those we've seen in the Vales, then I would be worried.' - Skalla, Captain of Vegbár

deed.name: Protectors of the Wilderfolk
deed.description: There is still much to do in the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: There is still more that can be done to make safe the Vales of Anduin.

questComplete.loreInfo: The Vales of the Anduin are beautiful, but their loveliness can mask deadly dangers. The Wilderfolk rely upon their own strength and that of travellers in their land to confront this danger and push it back.
questComplete.questCategory: Vales of Anduin: Protectors of the Wilderfolk

deed.name: Enemies of the Vales
deed.description: Conquer the many enemy encampments in the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Conquer the many enemy encampments in the Vales of Anduin.

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: Wargs have often ventured into the Beorning-lands over the years, but those that dwell at Ylgraf today are larger and more ferocious than others of their kind. These wargs come from Gundabad, and they slink among the rocks to the north of the Beorninghús, waiting to attack Grimbeorn and his kin.

The Beornings keep one eye on the Goblin-gate, for on this side of the mountains it is the primary way into, and out of, Goblin-town. During the last days of the War of the Ring, Orcs and goblins streamed through the Goblin-gate into the Vales of Anduin, raiding and burning peaceful Woodmen villages. Led by Grimbeorn the Old, the Beornings and Woodmen stood against the goblins and finally turned them back.
Now Goblin-town is quiet and there is little activity at the Goblin-gate, but the Beornings have not forgotten. They watch it still.

The peaceful Woodmen village of Waldfast has been destroyed by a goblin-host. Sentries are posted throughout the village, but their numbers are too few to explain the scope of the destruction. A cave behind the village might hold answers.

Following the final battles of the War of the Ring, a company of Orcs has established a tenuous foothold among the hills of Woodsedge. These are the Shapag-hai, and they have discovered they prefer to prey upon traders and travellers rather than warriors and soldiers. From their camp of Fil Sulmog they practice the art of pillaging, and have become quite good at it.

The forester camp of Tríubad provided timber and other necessary supplies with which the Woodmen built their homes and the walls of their villages, but then the Taurogrim came. The Woodmen name them 'Thyrsir,' wood-demons, and they fear their blighted touch.
The Woodmen know Tríubad may be lost, but they do not spend time in mourning. Instead they seek adventurers to stop the Thyrsir from spreading the blight to other villages in Woodsedge.

Côs Braen stands along the southern edge of Laerlad, home to the Ungoledain and their venomous kin. They hate Grimbeorn and his folk with a sickly passion, and would wipe out Beornings and Gauredain alike if they were given the chance.

Dredging machines stand in the mud of the Gladden Fields, once manned by Orc and half-orc, but now abandoned. A great hole was delved at Sharkey's Slough, and rumour has it that some prize was found in its depths. The half-orcs remain, seeking further treasures for themselves and not for their master. He remains silent, his thoughts elsewhere, and his servants at the Slough have received no message from him in some time.

Orcs searched the marshland for many weeks, operating from their camp of Lúlstrok in the north-western reaches the Gladden Fields. One of the great dredging machines stands there now, silent and still, but it once churned the earth during both day and night. Weapons, pieces of armour, and other trinkets were brought to Lúlstrok, but wherever these prizes may have gone in the time since is unknown.

What lies within the Warrens of Tûn Melen? Only by venturing within can you know for certain, but soldiers that serve the White Hand might already have done so, searching for treasure if not information.
landmarkDetection.progressOverride: Explore the Warrens of Tûn Melen

landmarkDetection.loreInfo: A wet mist soaks the stones that lead to Shathur-munzu, the southernmost outpost of lost Khazad-dûm. The fortress is broken now, and dwarves have not lived there for many years. Shathur-munzu was the site of one of the bloodiest battles in the War of Dwarves and Orcs, and King Thráin did not hold it long.

Ugúrz established his camp of Brafulug to prey upon traders on the road, believing his Orcs would be far enough from Lothlórien to escape the notice of the Elves. This would prove to be a miscalculation.

deed.name: Protectors of the Vales
deed.description: Explore the settlements of the Wilderfolk who live in the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Explore the settlements of the Wilderfolk who live in the Vales of Anduin.

landmarkDetection.loreInfo:
Home to Grimbeorn the Old and others of his family, the Beorninghús is generally closed to outsiders. During the final weeks of the War of the Ring, the Beornings found it necessary to take a more active role in the protection of the Vales of Anduin.
The sound of birdsong and the buzzing of dumbledors greet all who do approach the Beorninghús, but if they fail to ask Grimbeorn's permission, those are not the only sounds they will hear; Grimbeorn's wrath will be both loud and swift.

The outpost of Vegbár allows the Beornings to keep watch over the road between the High Pass and the Old Ford, and to charge their toll of travellers and traders who go that way. Skalla commands at Vegbár, and despite his gruff exterior he cares deeply for his neighbours and worries for their safety.

The forester Ainhard keeps a homestead in the Wolf-denes, and his closest companions are his three hounds. He lives in fear of Orcs, goblins, and taurogrim, for he is no warrior. He relies upon the nearby Beorning outpost of Vegbár for protection.
Hodver keeps a homestead in the Wolf-denes, but he is ever ready to make for the Beorning outpost of Vegbár at the first sign of Orcs or wargs. 'I am no coward,' he says, 'but I am no fool, either.'
Gudule keeps a homestead in the Wolf-denes. 'This land has never been safe,' he says. 'We live too near to the mountains to sleep very soundly at night. But this is home.'

The Woodmen town of Hultvís was attacked during the closing weeks of the War of the Ring, but the Orcs and wargs were pushed back and eventually defeated by a united force of Beornings and Woodmen at the Battle of the Old Ford. Now the town seeks to rebuild and refortify, and seeks adventurers willing to assist with the recovery effort.
The Woodmen are a superstitious people, and at Hultvís you are sure to hear many legends and tales. These concern the beautiful and forlorn Maiden of Gladden, the spectral Vagári the Wanderer, hunger-crazed Old Mad Ubb, and the vanished Hól-budlan.

The village of Blómgard is found in Laerlad, not far from the fens of the Gladden Fields. The Woodmen there speak in hushed whispers of an unnatural darkness and a scuttling sound on the roofs of their homes. The leader of Blómgard, Odahild, has a reputation for honesty and she is not one to speak falsely, but others in the Vales of Anduin question if the tales from Blómgard are true. An adventurer might get to the bottom of it.
This Beorning watchpost guards the road into Duskenvale. Elves also keep watch on the southern road, but neither trusts the other to do it alone.

Located not far from the lost dwarf fortress of Shathur-munzu, the village of Arhaim is occupied by both Woodmen and Beornings. Together they maintain trade with the Elves and live a simple life in Duskenvale.

At Glándir, the Elves guard the road into Lothlórien, maintaining the safety of the Golden Wood. Lady Galadriel and Lord Celeborn have been known to visit the Elves here on occasion, seeking reports from the Vales of Anduin and bringing food and cheer with them to relieve the burden of those Elves who stay outside the bounds of Lórien.

deed.name: Vales Beast and Insect Slayer
deed.description: Defeat many beasts and insects in the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Defeat many beasts and insects in the Vales of Anduin.

monsterDied.loreInfo: 'The Vales of Anduin are home to many varieties of beast and insect that will do you no harm. But there are others that have been seized by the darkness that crept out of Mirkwood, or have been tamed by the Orcs and goblins of the Misty Mountains. Oh yes, there are some that will do you a great deal of harm, if you let them! Show those foes no mercy, to save the rest!' - Radagast the Brown

The warg menace has been culled. The Wilderfolk of the Vales of Anduin are grateful for you aid.

deed.name: Vales Warg-slayer (Advanced)
deed.description: Defeat many wargs in the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Defeat many wargs in the Vales of Anduin.

monsterDied.loreInfo: 'Wargs range far and fast. They could be on you before you even knew they were there. If you travel at night, you might be wise to keep a campfire going. It would give away your position, but the wargs could smell you out anyway. They do not fear fire, but they do not like it, and it might deter them from testing you. Then again it might not. I will speak true: it is a tough decision. Perhaps it is best to travel only by day, after all.' - Ragnild of the Bear-folk
monsterDied.progressOverride: Defeat many wargs in the Vales of Anduin

deed.name: Protectors of the Wilderfolk (Advanced)

There is still more that can be done to make safe the Vales of Anduin.

questComplete.loreInfo: Much like Enedwaith on the far side of the Misty Mountains, the Vales of Anduin consist primarily of untamed wilderness, home to simple villages, hermits’ shelters, and only few roads. Most attempts to rule this wilderness have been short-lived and have long since fallen to ruin. You have done much to aid the Wilderfolk who live here, and made more secure a traditionally unsafe region.
questComplete.questCategory: Vales of Anduin: Protectors of the Wilderfolk

deed.name: Jumped At the Chance
deed.description: You looked across the ruins of the Hadhodiant and thought to yourself, 'I can make that jump!'

enterDetection.loreInfo: You looked across the ruins of the Hadhodiant and thought to yourself, 'I can make that jump!'
enterDetection.progressOverride: Attempted to cross the Hadhodiant

deed.name: Sites of the Vales
deed.description: Explore the many interesting locations to be found within the Vales of Anduin.

objective.text: Explore the many interesting locations to be found within the Vales of Anduin.

landmarkDetection.loreInfo:
The Eyrie of the Great Eagles can only be reached by flying. It is the home of Gwaihir the Windlord and his folk, perhaps the oldest denizens of the Vales of Anduin. They have ranged far and wide from this high perch, and their coming has always signaled a change in the tides of fate: during Bilbo's adventures with Thorin and Company, when Gandalf the Grey suffered imprisonment by Saruman the White, and during the concluding hours of the War of the Ring.
If you should come to the Eyrie, it is always to your benefit to be as polite as you can be to your hosts. Not all of the Great Eagles are friendly with outsiders or unwinged folk.

The High Pass through the Misty Mountains was treacherous and difficult to cross for many years, for both goblin raiders and stone-giants haunted the stones and crags and made travel difficult. When the Beornings arrived, the High Pass was cleared and they made an effort to push back these dangers. In return they charged a toll for passage, which other folk considered an unfair cost.
The High Pass was blocked during the War of the Ring, but today the Beornings have cleared it once again. Some say friendly stone-giants aided in this effort, but Grimbeorn's people will not say if this is so.

Hadhodiant was a mighty dwarf-bridge that served as the primary means of crossing the Anduin in the north, but it was broken shortly after the fall of Shathur-munzu in the Second Age. It was rebuilt, and indeed when the Great Alliance marched south to besiege Mordor, it was by way of the Hadhodiant that they crossed the Anduin.
But the bridge would not last. It broke in the middle, and when artisans from the Iron Hills were summoned to repair it, they were set upon by Orcs and every dwarf was slain. Over the course of centuries, stones of the bridge continued to fall into the river, until at last a tremendous flood swept away much of the ruin.
With the Hadhodiant destroyed, the Old Ford has come back into service as the primary means of crossing the Anduin in the north.

The old keep of Avabárg stands on a low islet in the river. Once home to the Horse-folk that would come to be known as the Éothéod, Avabárg now stands empty except for a gloom that has seized the island, and the occasional Orc or goblin that thinks to fortify the island and make it his own.
Woodmen have tried to reclaim it over the years, but each attempt ended in failure, and now they treat it with superstitious fear.

The village of Rhosgobel, once the northernmost settlement of the Wood-elves and later the southernmost, is now home only to Radagast the Brown, one of the five Wizards. For a time he chose a nomadic life and dwelled in Ost Guruth, the Ruin-hold in the Lone Lands, but now he has returned to Woodsedge and seeks to combat the encroaching darkness.

The course of the Gladden did not always run as it does today. During the fighting at the close of the Second Age, Sauron sent forth his dark thought, attempting to rouse great evils to his cause. Whether such calamities responded to him is unknown, but around this time there were massive quakes in the Misty Mountains, shaking the dwarf-halls as far north as the High Pass.
The upheaval changed the course of the river, carrying sediment downstream and choking the Gladdenmere until its banks overflowed. Water poured over the cliff, flooding the valley and submerging its roads. In this way, the Gladden Fields became a wide marsh of reeds and dark pools. In time the level of the lake was restored, and the Gladden Falls became the narrow torrent it is today.

deed.name: The Lost Lore of Rhovanion
deed.description: Complete all of the Lost Lore of Rhovanion.

objective.text: Complete all of the Lost Lore of Rhovanion.

questComplete.loreInfo: You have learned much about the difficulties the Dwarves of Erebor faced in the North, and how those troubles often took a familiar shape: Dragon!
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the North: Dwarves'

questComplete.loreInfo: You have learned about the tradition of the Black Arrow, a tradition which was kept alive by lords of Dale for hundreds of years. How fortunate that it was so! For it was Bard's Black Arrow that at last slew the dragon Smaug.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete: 'Lost Lore of the North: Men'

questComplete.loreInfo: You have learned a tale of the North that is all-too-familiar, for there are others like it. It is a tale of the enmity between Elves and dwarves, but in this case the tale goes further, to the healing between those folk, and that is a welcome difference.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the North: Elves'

questComplete.loreInfo: You have learned a song which tells the history of Járnfast. Like the Dwarves of the Iron Hills who dwell there, its fortunes were built almost entirely upon the material that gives that region its name, and the song its refrain: iron hard, and iron cold.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the Dwarf-holds: Ironfold'

questComplete.loreInfo: The lure of the ancient, lost city of Thafar-gathol has entranced the Zhélruka for much of their history, but despite many expeditions into the Grey Mountains it remains hidden, if it ever existed at all. You learned eight stanzas of a song extolling its virtues and its great wealth.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the Dwarf-holds: Ered Mithrin'

questComplete.loreInfo: You discovered a number of curious scratches in the hard stone of the Grey Mountains, and with much diligence you uncovered the full story. It is a cruel record of the dragon Smaug, and it tells of his growing fury and his desire for vengeance against the Dwarves of the North.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the Dwarf-holds: Smaug'

questComplete.loreInfo: As you discovered in Thikil-gundu, the Steel Keep of the Grey Mountains, not all of Sauron's servants gave up hope at the defeat of their master. Karazgar, the Weeping Warrior, devised a plan to ensnare the Herald of Winter, claiming he would not suffer defeat as Sauron did.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the Dwarf-holds: Thikil-gundu'

questComplete.loreInfo: You found every stanza for a bit of doggerel the Woodmen of the Vales of Anduin tell to their children: the song of Old Mad Ubb. He sounds like a rather unpleasant creature... and also a little familiar.
questComplete.progressOverride: Complete 'Lost Lore of the Vales: Old Mad Ubb'
Complete 'Lost Lore of the Vales: Tauralindalë'
